title: Logan Paul will address ‘Japan aftermath’ in documentary ahead of KSI rematch
text:
Logan is set to release a pre-fight documentary (Picture: Action Images via Reuters)

Logan Paul has revealed he’s set to address the ‘Japan aftermath’ in a documentary ahead of his rematch with KSI.

The YouTube star, who recently faced backlash for his comments to his opponent at the London press conference, announced the documentary on social media.

‘Back in LA. one month until the fight. look forward to our new Snapchat show “Countdown to Fight Night” later this month, as well as our boxing documentary following the japan aftermath, which will be the greatest piece of content I’ve ever released,’ he said.

Humble as ever.

The 24-year-old became public enemy number one back in early 2018, after he filmed a dead body in Aokigahara, known as Japan’s suicide forest.

He’s staying as humble as ever (Picture: Instagram/LoganPaul)

He later said that it ‘completely destroyed his image’.

‘In less than 24 hours I became the most hated person on the planet,’ the YouTuber recalled in a video at the end of 2018.

‘I had made an inexcusable mistake, completely destroyed my image, lost every professional relationship that I had, became the internet’s favourite meme and, most importantly, had my eyes opened wide to the consequences of my actions.’

Logan recently faced backlash for his comments to KSI (Picture: PA Wire)

Logan’s best friend Mike Majlak later claimed to Metro.co.uk that the horrific stunt had actually been ‘beneficial’ for him.

‘He’s worked on a lot of personal growth and he’s seen a lot of opportunity for growth in the days post-Tokyo and the days post-controversy,’ Mike said. ‘I think it’s apparent. For anybody to say he hasn’t made that growth, they’d be lying to themselves.’

Mike went on to say: ‘From a career standpoint for him, it may have caused quite a speed bump for him but, from a personal standpoint and the growth he’s made…It’s hard for me to say I’m happy it happened but I guess, looking back, I’m not unhappy that it happened.

‘In a lot of ways, I think that happening was very beneficial for him as a person.’
